ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal of grammar this semester and became more confident in my conversational italian.
I learned how to develop my grammar and speaking skills in Italian.
Knowledge of Italian vocabulary and grammar. Writing, conversation, and speaking skills. Knowledge of Italian culture.
Improvement in my Italian grammar
i learned a lot about italian culture and applicable uses of the language
A continuation of reading comprehension and writing from previous semesters; A greater emphasis on developing conversational skills
Improved my Italian speaking, listening, reading skills.
Conversational comfort in Italian. Review of grammar structures and vocabulary.
Increased knowledge of the Italian language, both spoken and written, as well as Italian culture.
I learned a lot about the Italian language and culture. The movies we watched for class were particularly helpful since we got to see how Italians lived (or how they lived on-screen).
I learned italian
I was able to revise the grammar structures learnt in L1 and L2 and apply them in more conversational settings.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the course was well organized to facilitate learning and engagement. Also the asynchronous Fridays were a huge plus. Weaknesses: sometimes the VHL activities were difficult / confusing and only had 1-2 attempts. Also, sometimes I found the workload to be slightly unmanageable
Strengths are the varying activities in and out of the classroom to keep engagement high and work on all areas of the language from listening, speaking, writing, and reading.

Strengths: Giacomos teaching style. Asynchronous Fridays. Textbook/ Syllabus. Cultural immersion activities like the language exchange and film watching. 

Weaknesses: Rather unforgiving attendance policy that does not seem fair nor safe in the age of COVID-19. Made me feel like I had to come to class even when I was ill and could put others at risk. Also was not very inclusive of other struggles like personal issues.
There could be more talking and speaking involved in the course in person.
the small class sizes helped me learn the language better with more attention from the professor
The course is well facilitated to encourage a high level of engagement and constant learning.

I wish we didn't redo all the grammar from L1 and L2. I think that it's unnecessary. I would've liked to just watch movies, do audio exercises, listen to songs, read stories, etc to improve our understanding and literacy of the language.
Giacomo is fantastic, and I really like that the course is more of a review than learning new grammar. It puts focus on comfort in becoming conversational.

This course is a great review of the skills we learned in L1 and L2. However, at times it was repetitive, especially in the beginning when we went all the way back to the basics I was already very confident in.

You really can't go wrong with any of the professors in the Italian department and Giacomo is no exception. He's very passionate about language learning and Italian and gives you the flexibility to talk about and learn more about whatever aspect of Italian culture you're curious about.

The only weakness I can think about was the disconnect between what we talked about in class and the content in the textbook. I wish we discussed the subject areas in the textbook a bit more.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I loved all three semesters of Italian I have taken at Yale and truly feel that I have learned a great deal of the language and Italian culture
I would becuase I think the Italian department does a very good job of workload and engagement.

Yes. The Italian department is truly so special. Giacomo is an incredible instructor who is so accessible and interesting. The class exposed me to so many important topics and to Italian culture in general.
Yes, if you want to continue Italian, take this course.
only as a requirement
Yes, Italian is a beautiful language.
Absolutely.
Yes, Italian is objectively the best language, and the Italian department faculty are objectively the best instructors.
I would absolutely recommend this course! The entire Italian department is always so kind and helpful, and I love how open they are to students with their many events throughout the year.
Yes, best language department at Yale.
